intro.text:
Hello, I am Detective Ward. We just picked you up from the Memorial Hospital.

Your head is pounding as you digest what the man just told you

The doctor claim you have retrograde amnesia.. Do you think you can tell me your name?

You feel your mind scatter trying to find a name but it feels just out of reach
I thought so.. You are the owner of Neon Pulse, a very popular bar downtown.
About that.. Dr. Vaughn is dead.

A damned famous scientist - pioneered research on mechanical instruments. More importantly, a friend of yours.

Vaughn sounded vaguely familar and yet you could not put a pin on it
He was found dead in your bar, you and three others were found unconscious next to him
Also, there was a poison compound that was found in his body. Your bloodwork report did not show anything. So you are safe
I understand all of this is far too much for you to comprehend and understand all at once. But this is a high profile case that we want to keep moving, is there anything you can tell us?

choices.label: I want to help. Tell me what you know.
I still do not understand why I am here? You’re wasting your time...

Wait here for a moment
Finally having a moment to think for yourself, you try and remember who Vaughn could be. Who could the three others be?

What do you think this is?
You examine the device kept in front of you and something stratches at the back of your mind.
Listen to me very carefully. From what we understand, Dr. Vaughn was engaged in some unauthorized research
We don't know the scope of it yet but this device was found at the murder scene next to you
plotline1.buttonText: Could this have anything to do with my memories?

plotline1.text: A Hypothesis. That's all we have regarding what happened to your memories. Once again, doctors say that it was blunt force trauma.

We have already interrogated the others, Etta Moreau, Jonas Reyes and Silas Mercer

As the detective rattled of these names, you could not help but feel a sense of familiarity

Mr. Mercer was the one we cared about the most due to his expertise in mechanical stuff

You could feel the detective trying to use that information to get something out of you. But you-

You could feel the detective trying to use that information to get something out of you. But you-

You feel yourself getting pulled into a memory..

I know it is risky but I trust you.
Anyway, I understand all of this is too much for you. So, if anything comes up we'll reach out. Do not leave the state while the investigation is ongoing.
<em>What was that? A memory? Did you use that contraption? Is that why you lost your memory? Feeling dazed you walk out of the police station.<em>

<em>One name stood out to you. Silas Mercer. Gut instinct told you that he would know what happened.. or at least help you piece something together. As you mulled the name Silas, something in you clicked and instictively you knew where to go.<em>
Who's th-? Ah, it's you.
It was a matter of time before you wandered off here. I thought all of your memories were gone?
So, nothing. What brings you here?
plotline1.buttonText: I thought, you would be able to help me

plotline1.text: And why, pray tell, would I do that?
plotline1.buttonText: Because I have the feeling you know more than you are letting on

plotline1.text: Of course I know more. He was OUR friend. But I am not going to sell him or the others out like that
<em>He sighs, walks over to a worn drawer, and carefully pulls out a strange, mechanical device. It clicks softly in his hands.<em>
This is what Vaughn was working on. He always said this would be the thing they remembered him for.
I didn’t think it would come to this. I thought he stopped it.

choices.label: If I was responsible for this, I need to fix things
If we want the truth, we need to go to the detective—together.
Help me, or I start talking — your name comes up first.

earlyEnding1.text: Silas looks at you for a long moment, conflicted. Then he nods slowly.
“Alright. If there’s even a chance it helps… I’ll go with you.”
You both head to the station. As soon as the device is presented, the atmosphere shifts. Officers glance at each other. The detective’s expression hardens.
“Where did you get this?” the detective asks sharply.
Silas remains silent. His jaw clenches.
“This device was active recently. You’re telling me you had no part in what happened to Vaughn?”
You watch as Silas refuses to defend himself—not out of guilt, but loyalty. He looks at you once. Then looks away.
“Silas Mercer, you’re under arrest for obstruction and suspected involvement in an ongoing investigation.”
The door closes behind him. Just like that, he’s gone.

plotline2.text:
You rolled a {roll}.
I understand you’ve been through a lot, but I don't have to sit here while you play games.
Detective Ward stands up and walks toward the door. You feel like you've hit a wall and the questions only multiply.
He opens the door without looking back. “We’ll be in touch.” Just like that, you’re out.

You stumble outside into the cold night. The hospital wristband still clings to your arm.
The city hums — distant, indifferent. But something pulls you east. You just know where to go.
As you step inside, the air is thick with vinyl jazz and stale smoke. Behind the counter, a tall man in suspenders wipes a glass.
He sees you and pauses. “Well I’ll be... Look who finally woke up.”
His face feels familiar — warm, somehow. But the details are foggy.
“Rough couple days, huh?” Jonas leans against the counter. “Heard you were out cold. Sorry about Vaughn... Hell of a way to go.”
You feel a lump forming in your throat.
He gives you a look — half pity, half confusion. “I was hopin’ you’d tell *me*.”
You pause. Something clicks. You own this place — there must be cameras.
plotline2.buttonText: Wait. Don’t we have security footage?

plotline2.text: “Yeah, yeah. We keep ‘em in the back.” Jonas calls over a young bartender. “Hey Mickey, go grab the tapes from that night, would ya?”
You wait. The music plays on. Jonas lights a cigarette.
plotline2.buttonText: You sure we even recorded that night?

plotline2.text: “'Course you did. You've had that setup running since ’83.”
Mickey returns, empty-handed. “Uh… boss… The tapes are gone. Like, all of ‘em. Just static.”
Jonas frowns. “Either someone messed with ‘em, or they were wiped clean. Ain’t no accident, I’ll tell you that.”

choices.label: We have to take the tapes to the cops.
Let me look around some more.

earlyEnding2.text: The detectives sit in front of you, their faces stern and unwavering. A long silence hangs in the air.
Detective Ward looks at you with a hard stare, his voice cold and accusatory. “You’re the only one with the kind of access to the tapes. All evidence points to you tampering with them.”

You try to protest, but the weight of the situation is heavy on your chest. The room feels suffocating as Detective Ward continues, “The case is closed. We can’t charge you with anything, but that doesn’t make you innocent.”

You’re left with nothing but silence as they file out of the room. Your name is cleared, but the mystery surrounding Dr. Vaughn’s death remains unsolved. The weight of what happened is on your shoulders.
As you sit there, the cold realization sinks in. The case may be closed, but for you, it’s far from over. The detectives may think you’re off the hook, but you know there’s more to this story.
But for now, there’s nothing you can do.

plotline3.text:
You rolled a {roll}.

The detective’s face shifts — the warmth is gone.

“Alright, I’m done wasting my time.”

Ward snaps the file shut and glares at you. “You can go. You’re not under arrest — yet.”
The officer at the door doesn’t look at you as you’re escorted out into the rain-slicked alley behind the station.

A silhouette leans against the brick wall, a cigarette glowing in the dim light.

“Knew you’d piss him off somehow,” she says, lips curling into a familiar smirk.

She steps forward, brushing a strand of hair behind her ear. Her tone is soft, sultry.

“Still can’t remember a damn thing, huh?”

You shake your head. She sighs, placing a gentle hand on your shoulder.

“It’s alright. Everything’s gonna be fine. You’ve been through worse.”
“Vaughn... he wasn’t just playing with wires and gears,” she murmurs. “He was into something darker. Unauthorized research — on memory manipulation.”
She looks away. “I don’t know everything. But before he died, he kept saying someone was watching him. He was scared. Paranoid.”
“There’s someone who might know more,” she says, her voice dropping to a whisper. “Come on. I’ll take you to Silas. He worked with Vaughn... back before things got weird.”
You and Etta wind your way through dim backstreets until she stops in front of an old wooden storefront. The sign above reads: ‘Silas & Co. – Timepieces and Repairs’.
The inside is dim and cluttered — ticking clocks fill the silence. A tall man with grease-streaked hands looks up from a dismantled timepiece.

“Etta,” he says curtly, wiping his hands. His eyes land on you.

“And You. Well... damn.”
He walks closer, inspecting you quietly. “You really don’t remember, do you?”

He nods slowly. “It’s a hell of a thing, losing someone like Vaughn.”

His voice cracks slightly. “We weren’t always on the best terms. But he was... family.”
“None of us ever expected this,” Etta murmurs. “He was brilliant, maybe a little broken... but he didn’t deserve this.”
plotline3.buttonText: What was he working on? Something about... memory?

plotline3.text: Silas stiffens. “Don’t dig. Not now. It won’t bring him back.”

“I said let it lie.”

Etta snorts. “Of course you’d say that. You were always too afraid to take responsibility.”
Silas glares at her. “I warned him. Over and over. But he wouldn’t listen.”
Etta crosses her arms. “Warned him and still let him spiral? That’s rich.”
“You think I didn’t try?” Silas snaps. “He shut everyone out. Whatever he was working on... it scared even him.”
You look between them, piecing together fragments. Vaughn, paranoia, secrecy. A machine that tampers with memory.
“He said someone was watching,” Etta mutters. “Started locking everything. Even the notes.”
“And you didn't think to tell me any of this?” you ask, your voice rising.
“We didn’t know what was real,” Silas says quietly. “Vaughn barely did.”
Etta’s eyes narrow. “He needed help. Instead, we argued, and now he’s gone.”
You feel the weight of their guilt. But you also feel the missing pieces closing in, too many blanks, too many lies.

choices.label: Vaughn was our friend. We need to be honest with each other.
This feels off. Someone set us up, and I’ll find out who.
Tell me everything. Or I take you both to the cops.
